prompt.question:

db.createCollection('latest_news', {'capped': true, 'size': 10000, 'max': 3})


[

db.latest_news.insertOne({title: 'TikTok owner ByteDance dissolves its investment arm'})

prompt.question: Data modeling. You are considering the use of nesting or references in your data model. Your data may change frequently. Which option would be more appropriate?
answers: Use of reference.
Use of nesting.

prompt.question: Data modeling. You are considering the use of nesting or references in your data model. Documents can grow rapidly. Which option would be more appropriate?
answers: Use of reference.
Use of nesting.

prompt.question: Data modeling. You are considering the use of nesting or the references in your data model. Data read operations must be fast. Which option would be more appropriate?
answers: Use of reference.
Use of nesting.

prompt.question: Select all true statements about MongoDB documents.
answers: MongoDB documents have a flexible schema.
MongoDB documents are stored as BSON documents.
MongoDB documents are stored as JSON documents.
MongoDB documents must have the same fields in the collection.

prompt.question: Which of the following constraints might impact your data model for MongoDB?
answers: RAM
Network
Security & Compliance
Operating System

prompt.question: How can we represent a one-to-one relationship in MongoDB?
answers: We can embed fields in the document.
We can embed fields as a child document in the document.
We can link to a single document in another collection.

prompt.question: Select all true statements about one-to-zillions relationships (a special case of the one-to-many relationship in MongoDB).
answers: Representing this relationships with document embedding is not recommended.
We need to be extremely careful when writing queries that retrieve data on the zillions side.
This relationship is created to emphasize the fact that huge cardinalities can impact design choices.

prompt.question: Which of the following scenarios best suits the use of the Tree Pattern?
answers: Product categories in the online store.
You want to store additional information about your products that are less used by your application.

prompt.question: Select all true statements about data modeling in MongoDB.
answers: MongoDB can easily handle both unstructured and structured data sets.
Unlike SQL databases, where the table schema must be specified and declared before inserting the data, MongoDB collections don't, by default, require documents to have the same schema.
The field set and data type for each field can differ across documents within a collection.
In MongoDB we can enforce document validation rules for a collection during update and insert operations.

prompt.question:
Let's consider a one-to-many relationship observed between an instructor and the courses he is created on an e-learning platform. We assume that a course can only have one instructor, and an instructor can have multiple courses.


Which of the following are the correct ways to represent this one-to-many relationship with a document model in MongoDB?
prompt.explanation:
Embed all the fields for a course as a subdocument in the corresponding instructor document.

These subdocuments must be put into an array, not stored directly as a subdocument in its parent. This way we can have a variable number of referenced documents and use a multi-key index to search the "many" side. This is not the best way to do it.


https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/model-embedded-one-to-many-relationships-between-documents/
answers: Embed the entities for the courses as an array of sub-documents in the corresponding instructor document.
Have a collection for the instructors and a collection for the courses with each course document having a field to reference the document of its instructor.
Embed all the fields for a course as a subdocument in the corresponding instructor document.

prompt.question:
Consider a many-to-many relationship observed between courses and the students enrolled in these courses.


Which of the following are true about modeling this many-to-many relationship with the document model in MongoDB?
answers: Embedding students in courses duplicates student information.
Embedding students in courses still requires a separate collection to store all students (we may have students who are not enrolled in any course).
When using one collection for students and one collection for courses there is a need for an array of references in only one collection.
The many-to-many relationship cannot be represented in MongoDB.

prompt.question:
Consider a one-to-one relationship observed between users and the users details. Basic information about application users is separated from detailed information.


Which of the following are true about modeling this one-to-one relationship with the document model in MongoDB?
answers: We can embed fields with detailed information in the users collection.
We can embed fields with detailed information as a subdocument in the users collection.
We can link to a single document with detailed information in another collection.

prompt.question: Which of the following scenarios is best suited for applying the Attribute Pattern?
answers: You need to apply document validation before inserting/modifying.
Some fields share a similar characteristics, and you want to search across those fields.
The documents in the collection are quite large.

prompt.question:
Suppose you have a mobile_games collection with the following document structure:


{
    game: "Fishing Clash",
    company: "Ten Square Games",
    platforms: ['Android', 'IOS'],
    ...
    release_USA: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00"),
    release_France: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00"),
    release_Italy: ISODate("2017-08-17T01:00:00+01:00"),
    ...
}


You want to redesign your document structure as below:


{
    game: "Fishing Clash",
    company: "Ten Square Games",
    platforms: ['Android', 'IOS'],
    …
    releases: [
        {
        location: "USA",
        date: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00")
        },
        {
        location: "France",
        date: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00")
        },
        {
        location: "Italy",
        date: ISODate("2017-08-17T01:00:00+01:00")
        },
        … 
    ],
    … 
}


Which pattern solution will you use to solve this problem?
answers: The Attribute Pattern.
The Bucket Pattern.
The Extended Reference Pattern.
The Subset Pattern.
The Schema Versioning Pattern.

prompt.question:
Suppose you have a mobile_games collection with the following document structure:


{
    game: "Fishing Clash",
    company: "Ten Square Games",
    platforms: ['Android', 'IOS'],
    ...
    release_USA: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00"),
    release_France: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00"),
    release_Italy: ISODate("2017-08-17T01:00:00+01:00"),
    ...
}


Are there any problems with this document structure?
answers: Yes, a search for a release date will require looking across many fields at once which is inefficient.
No, everything is correct. There is no room for improvement.

prompt.question:
Suppose you have a mobile_games collection with the following document structure to redesign:


{
    game: "Fishing Clash",
    company: "Ten Square Games",
    platforms: ['Android', 'IOS'],
    ...
    release_USA: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00"),
    release_France: ISODate("2017-04-09T01:00:00+01:00"),
    release_Italy: ISODate("2017-08-17T01:00:00+01:00"),
    ...
}


Which pattern solution is best suited for this situation?
answers: The Attribute Pattern.
The Bucket Pattern.
The Extended Reference Pattern.
The Subset Pattern.
There is no need to redesign the document structure.

prompt.question:
Use case: e-learning platform


Which of the following scenarios is the best candidate to use the Extended Reference Pattern to avoid additional reads by joins/lookups?
answers: Our app needs to retrieve a course and information about its instructor.
Our app needs to retrieve a course and its ten most recent reviews.
A course model needs to store a counter representing the number of times it was purchased.
A course model needs to store references to image of the course that are kept in an external location outside the database.

prompt.question:
Use case: e-learning platform


Which of the following scenarios is the best candidate to use the Subset Pattern?
answers: Our app needs to retrieve a course and its ten most recent reviews.
Our app needs to retrieve a course and information about its instructor.
A course model needs to store a counter representing the number of times it was purchased.
A course model needs to store references to image of the course that are kept in an external location outside the database.

prompt.question:
Use case: e-learning platform


Which of the following scenarios is the best candidate to use the Computed Pattern?
answers: A course model needs to store a counter representing the number of times it was purchased.
Our app needs to retrieve a course and its ten most recent reviews.
Our app needs to retrieve a course and information about its instructor.
A course model needs to store references to image of the course that are kept in an external location outside the database.

prompt.question:
We can use this pattern to work with different schema versions. It mainly involves adding a new field to the document structure, such as schema_version. This field will allow our application to know how to handle particular document.


Which pattern does this description apply to?
answers: The Schema Versioning Pattern.
The Outlier Pattern.
The Subset Pattern.
The Attribute Pattern.
The Polymorphic Pattern.

prompt.question: Select scenarios that are best suited for applying the Schema Versioning Pattern.
answers: Your team was assigned to update the current schema with additional fields without shutting down the system for this upgrade. However, all documents need to be quickly updated.
There is a requirement to keep multiple versions of a document, and those versions can have different fields for each version in your application.

prompt.question: Select true statements about data modeling in MongoDB.
answers: It's good data modeling practice to directly map each table from the relational model (normalized data) to the collection.
If one of your application's main queries is to retrieve related information from different collections, it is usually better to group that information into a single document.
To avoid having to join data in the application layer from different collections you can denormalize your data.

prompt.question: Select all true statements regarding to schema validation in MongoDB.
answers: MongoDB doesn't provide the capability to perform schema validation during updates and insertions.
Validation rules are on a per-collection basis.
We need to use db.createCollection() with the validator option to specify validation rules for a new collection.

prompt.question: Select all true statements regarding to transactions in MongoDB.
answers: The collections used in a transaction can be in different databases.
We cannot read/write to collections in the config, admin, or local databases.
Transactions are associated with a session.

prompt.question: Select read concern levels that are supported by transactions in MongoDB.
answers: local
majority
snapshot

prompt.question: What is data modeling in MongoDB world?
answers: A way to organize fields in a document to support your application performance and querying capabilities.
A way to build your application based on how your data is stored.
A way to decide whether to store your data in the cloud or locally.
A way to show your database with graphs.

prompt.question:
A social media company needs to implement a data model that describes te relationships between users. When loading real data into the system, it turned out that one user has too many contacts to store them in the designated array.

Instead of redesigning the entire system what pattern can you use?
answers: The Outlier Pattern.
The Schema Versioning Pattern.
The Subset Pattern.
The Attribute Pattern.
The Extended Reference Pattern.

prompt.question: Select true statements about capped collections.
answers: Capped collections are fixed-size collections.
If the collection is full, the oldest document in the collection is removed when a new document is added to the collection.
Capped collections guarantee preservation of the insertion order.
Capped collections automatically remove the oldest documents in the collection to make room for new documents.

prompt.question: What command can you use to create a capped collection named latest_news that will be limited to 3 documents and 10,000 bytes?
answers: db.createCollection('latest_news', {'capped': true, 'size': 10000, 'max': 3})
db.createCollection('latest_news', {'capped': true, 'max': 3})
db.createCollection('latest_news', {'size': 10000, 'max': 3})
